awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Broad Spectrum biorational bio- and synthetic insecticides and mosquito repellents
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this SBIR project proposing a novel broad spectrum insecticide safe for humans, expected to be safer than synthetic insecticides.  It will be used in conventional and organic farming, as well as personal protection/mosquito repellent products, costing significantly less than the products currently on the market. Crop losses due to insect pests cost billions of dollars and the limited classes of insecticides are vulnerable to the constant threat of resistance.  In addition, the lack of specificity creates broad risks due to pesticide residues polluting food and water and causing environmental damage. In particular, organic farming needs effective bioinsecticides for economically sustainable yields. The proposed product will have applications to other mosquito-borne diseases without adverse effects on human health.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to combine an effective insect protein target with a new class of molecules. In particular, a single molecule and its analogs derived from easily produced and cheaply priced natural products create new options for cost-effective and scalable de-novo synthesis for mass production. A few separate molecules from this general class have been shown to possess the right mechanism of insecticidal activity specific to insects (not humans). The specific protein target has a well conserved active site across arthropods (insects). Preliminary technical feasibility has been established and the Phase I work plan will validate proof-of-concept for the proposed solution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In phase I the cost-effective denovo synthesis of the proposed novel (US patent pending) broad spectrum bio- and synthetic insecticides and mosquito repellents was developed. The broad spectrum insecticidal activity was tested in third party trials as an insecticidal seed coating that was also combined with the company?s proprietary fungicidal seed coating since insecticides and fungicides are applied together to seeds to enable vigor and a good stand count. The spatial repellency and contact irritancy against mosquitos alongside a well known and ubiquitous mosquito repellent DEET was validated in third party trials and showed that our proposed eco-friendly mosquito repellents are significantly more effective than DEET under similar concentrations. Developing safe mosquito and insect repellents has been a long standing challenge however, products in the market are not as effective. Unlike synthetic insecticides and DEET based mosquito repellents on the market, our novel broad spectrum bio- and synthetic insecticides and mosquito repellents are safe for the humans and bees. Insecticides are an essential component of modern agriculture be in conventional or organic. Synthetic insecticides are based on non specific insect targets that can be and often are extremely toxic to growers, pesticide applicators, and consumers with many of them being neurotoxins. Currently available bioinsecticides have to be applied preemptively and are not reliable and effective. In addition to organic production systems, bioinsecticides are widely applied in conventional production systems as part of integrated pest management. Therefore, the bio- and synthetic insecticides developed by the company have an excellent crossover potential between organic and conventional production systems and wide applicability to home owners, small growers, large growers, and indoor agriculture. Because the proposed small molecules can be synthesized cost-effectively, their cost-efficacy will enhance competitiveness of US agriculture. The successful implementation of the Phase I effort has set the stage for a meaningful Phase II where in the company will: 1) scale up denovo synthesis to pilot scale production of the active ingredients; 2) develop formulations for ease of delivery and further increase in efficacy; and 3) small plot and demo trials of our formulated insecticides.

Our proposed product will effectively address all the problems mentioned below. Crop losses due to insect pests run in to billions of dollars. The limited classes of insecticides are vulnerable to the constant threat of insecticide resistance. New ways of controlling insect pests are urgently needed for both conventional and organic farming as evidenced by the recent outbreak of citrus greening caused by Asian citrus psyllids in California, Florida, and other states. In addition, due to non-specific insecticidal mechanisms of existing insecticides on the market, pesticide residues pollute food and water and cause environmental damage. Organic farming in particular needs effective bioinsecticides for economically sustainable yields. Mosquitoes are important disease vectors as further emphasized by recent concerns with Zika virus and the proposed product will have applications in spatial repellency and toxicity to mosquitoes without any adverse effects on human health.

The company is rapidly moving forward to commercialize the proposed and other related Ag biotechnologies developed by the company. It has a very successful track record of developing defensible intellectual property and has three US patents issued for its certain other Ag biotechnology products. The environmental sustainability challenge necessitates a meaningful reform of agricultural practices from the grounds up. The current organic agriculture paradigm has led to a niche production system that has failed to become mainstream. Conventional growers wanting to switch from conventional to organic often fail to transition their acreage to organic due to lack of effective inputs for organic production systems and access to markets especially during the three year transitional phase from conventional to organic before their produce can be sold as certified organic. Biomineral Systems has developed a complete solution for the growers that includes fertilizers, seed treatments, fungicide, insecticide, herbicide, and biopolymers that are each based on unique technologies and that together provide a three fold winning strategy of cost leadership; clear differentiation from existing products; and efficacy similar to the corresponding best in class synthetics. Funding from the National science foundation that supported our product development for the insecticide and mosquito repellents as part of this award and broad spectrum biofungicide as part of a previous award is key to the successful development of these products.


Last Modified: 12/15/2021
Modified by: Nadia Adam
